changes: [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aē', 'str': 'aē for a', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'e', 'str': 'e inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ōi', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for ōi', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "This feature represents a confusion within a broader group of spellings including aō, ōi, aōi, and ō. This confusion arises because all these forms were likely pronounced as ō or ū. While ōi for aō 'does not usually occur' as a general rule in Iranian manuscripts, it can be found in specific contexts, such as the genitive singular forms of u-stems (e.g., rašnaōš vs. rašnōiš), where there might be influence from i-stems. In Indian manuscripts, this type of confusion, including ō for ōi and ōi for ō, is frequently observed"}]

In this context, unstressed vowels, including u, tend to be elided when they occur before nasals, liquids, and semivowels. While not explicitly listed as a standalone feature solely for u, it is encompassed by the general pattern of short vowel syncope."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'o', 'to': 'ōi', 'str': 'ōi for o', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'e', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for e', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'common confusions among short palatal vowels (ə, e, i)'}]

[{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'h', 'str': 'h deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'The loss of aspiration (h) is a significant orthographic and phonological feature influenced by modern recitation practices. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. This change is particularly prevalent in later Iranian copies from the 19th century, where ā replaces ā̊ in a high percentage of occurrences (over 75% in some manuscripts). Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. In contrast, Indian manuscripts exhibit different behaviours for ā̊, such as its use for āu or its graphical representation as ā/ə in line-breaks, implying a pronunciation similar to /āo/ or /āe/'}]

[{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'e', 'str': 'e deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his is part of a broader phenomenon of short vowel loss in Iranian manuscripts, especially in later copies. This syncope is linked to the 'allegro' (fast) recitation style, particularly prevalent among Zoroastrian speakers in Yazd. In such contexts, unstressed short vowels, including e, are prone to elision, especially in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. While specific examples of e deletion are not singled out from the general rule, it falls under the documented tendency for short vowels to disappear."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ṣ̌', 'to': 'š', 'str': 'š for ṣ̌', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'aō', 'to': 'ōi', 'str': 'ōi for aō', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'aō for ō are also frequent in Iranian manuscripts, especially during the Zand period'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā̊', 'to': 'āu', 'str': 'āu for ā̊', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the dominant trend is the disappearance of ā̊, evolving into ā. This is considered a 'loss of a distinctive vowel'. Therefore, ā̊ for ā would primarily represent an inverse spelling or a 'wrong transcription' in this tradition"}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'uu', 'to': 'u', 'str': 'u for uu', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'uu replaces short u, lengthening effect common in Indian copies.'}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ə', 'to': 'aē', 'str': 'aē for ə', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "While ə is described as a 'shading of a' in Indian manuscripts, and Jackson notes a in Behdini can lean towards an 'inverted a' or 'close to e', this is more of a pronunciation tendency or a description of the vowel's quality rather than a common orthographic substitution in the way ə substitutes i or e"}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ai', 'to': 'ii', 'str': 'ii for ai', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'The sources discuss ii primarily in relation to ī (and y/ẏ), where uu for ū and ii for ī are described as a scriptural convention in Indian manuscripts influenced by Gujarati orthography, with inverse spellings also occurring'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ą̇', 'to': 'ą', 'str': 'ą for ą̇', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'ą̇ is standard in Indian manuscripts, ą in Iranian ones.'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ōi', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for ōi', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "This feature represents a confusion within a broader group of spellings including aō, ōi, aōi, and ō. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). This is part of the general confusion of short vowels ('i', 'e', 'ə'). While Indian manuscripts show frequent 'i' for 'ə' and 'i' for 'e', a direct 'a' for 'i' is not highlighted as a distinct feature."}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 't', 'str': 't deleted', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. [{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'ī', 'str': 'ī deleted', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ą̇', 'to': 'ą', 'str': 'ą for ą̇', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'ą̇ is standard in Indian manuscripts, ą in Iranian ones.'}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'āi', 'to': 'ā', 'str': 'ā for āi', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'i', 'to': 'ə̄', 'str': 'ə̄ for i', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'e', 'str': 'e deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his is part of a broader phenomenon of short vowel loss in Iranian manuscripts, especially in later copies. This syncope is linked to the 'allegro' (fast) recitation style, particularly prevalent among Zoroastrian speakers in Yazd. In such contexts, unstressed short vowels, including e, are prone to elision, especially in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. While specific examples of e deletion are not singled out from the general rule, it falls under the documented tendency for short vowels to disappear."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā̊', 'to': 'ā', 'str': 'ā for ā̊', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the dominant trend is the disappearance of ā̊, evolving into ā. It is attributed to the influence of Gujarati, where h is often pronounced softly or omitted, particularly in medial position'}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'u', 'str': 'u deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "his phenomenon is part of a broader tendency for the loss of short vowels in Iranian manuscripts, especially noticeable in later copies. It is particularly characteristic of the Yazdi Behdini recitation tradition, which often features an 'allegro' or fast pronunciation. In this context, unstressed vowels, including u, tend to be elided when they occur before nasals, liquids, and semivowels. While not explicitly listed as a standalone feature solely for u, it is encompassed by the general pattern of short vowel syncope."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aē', 'str': 'aē for a', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'e', 'str': 'e inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ą̇', 'to': 'ą', 'str': 'ą for ą̇', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'ą̇ is standard in Indian manuscripts, ą in Iranian ones.'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'š', 'to': 'ṣ̌', 'str': 'ṣ̌ for š', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'š used for ṣ̌ (written ṣ̌), common simplification.'}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'a', 'str': 'a deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ą̇', 'to': 'ą', 'str': 'ą for ą̇', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'ą̇ is standard in Indian manuscripts, ą in Iranian ones.'}]

This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'e', 'to': 'ē', 'str': 'ē for e', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a common feature of vowel quantity change observed in Indian manuscripts. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ē', 'to': 'ī', 'str': 'ī for ē', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, this is noted as an inverse spelling.The tendency for long palatal vowels in Iranian manuscripts is to close ē into ī, so ē for ī would be an opposing or 'inverse' trend."}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'i', 'to': 'e', 'str': 'e for i', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'common confusions among short palatal vowels (ə, e, i)'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Iranian manuscripts, the confusion of 'a' for 'i' occurs, especially before nasals or after 'r' (e.g., 'tną' for 'tą', 'ϑrətiia-' for 'ϑritiia-'). [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. This change is particularly prevalent in later Iranian copies from the 19th century, where ā replaces ā̊ in a high percentage of occurrences (over 75% in some manuscripts). Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'š', 'to': 'ṣ̌', 'str': 'ṣ̌ for š', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'š used for ṣ̌ (written ṣ̌), common simplification.'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'aō', 'str': 'aō for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'In Indian manuscripts, a for aō is a form of monophthongization, though it is relatively less frequent compared to u for aō'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'o', 'str': 'o inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]
